newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: RUGBY UNION-ZONDAGH RESIGNS AS W.P. COACH.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION-ZONDAGH RESIGNS AS W.P. COACH.

text.p: Beleaguered Western Province rugby coach Alan Zondagh resigned from his position on Thursday, the Western Province Rugby Football Union (WPRFU) announced in a press statement.
Zondagh resigned halfway through a fresh two-year contract, citing a poor 1996 season and mounting pressures from the public and the media as his main reasons.
Under Zondagh's reign for three years, Western Province won the 1994 Lion Cup final and lost in the final of the 1995 Currie Cup to Natal.

But the province seemed to lose direction this season with a string of erratic performances and, having been the strength of South African domestic rugby a decade ago, they were not good enough this year to qualify for the Super 12 competition.

"Perhaps he (Zondagh) lacked the ability to motivate his players, but this is where a captain capable of taking over the inspirational duties would have been the perfect combination. Unfortunately, no one was prepared to take on the role," WPRFU Ronni Masson president told a Cape Town newspaper on Thursday.
Assistant coach Gert Smal has been tipped as Zondagh's possible successor while former captain Tiaan Strauss, back from rugby league in Australia, could make a return to the side.
